text: The only known form of phototrophy in archaea is that of retinal-based ion pumps.

Methanogenesis includes a unique pathway of carbon fixation, called the carbon monoxide reductase pathway because the key into acetyl-CoA by condensation with a methyl group generated by methanogenesis.
It turns out that haloarchaea have transferred genes encoding light-absorbing proton pumps into many marine bacteria.
By contrast, the chlorophyll-based phototrophy found in bacteria and plants is completely unknown in archaea.

Membrane protein complexes known as bacteriorhodopsin and halorhodopsin contain Bacteriorhodopsins are found in haloarchaea (formerly called halobacteria) such as Halobacterium halobium; the species was named before it was known to be an archaeon (discussed in Section 19.5).

On the other hand, halophilic archaea such as Halobacterium phosphorylate the dehydrated product of gluconate (2-oxo-3-deoxygluconate), which enters the “standard” of pyruvate and one molecule of 3-phosphoglycerate, energy-yielding reaction.
Methane production by methanogenic archaea (methanogens) makes a growing contribution to global warming, as discussed in Chapter 22.
The energy-yielding process of methanogenesis occurs only in archaea.
is still produced by further breakdown of pyruvate.)
